newsitem.title: INDIA: Bombay shares end 3.7 pct down on shattered hopes.
newsitem.headline: Bombay shares end 3.7 pct down on shattered hopes.

text.p: ** Bombay shares finish 3.7 percent lower in volatile trade
after much-publicised market "package" from government
fails to come through, traders say
** Prime Minister H.D. Deve Gowda goes to Davos for World
Economic Forum leaving stunned traders in his wake
** Benchmark stocks index plummets 130.30 points or 3.7
percent to provisional close of 3379.75 as traders
liquidate long positions
** National bourse's 50-stocks index ends 28.60 points or
2.86 percent down at 971.40
** Index stocks Reliance, SBI, TISCO and ITC -- which
have risen sharply on hopes of market help -- lead crash
Bombay shares plunged 3.7 percent on Friday as stunned speculators cut long positions after keenly anticipated new market policy initiatives failed to come through, traders said.
"The Prime Minister kept saying he was going to make policy announcements...and then he vanished," said a trader at a foreign brokerage.
"It's hurt his credibility badly. Speculators were forced to unwind their positions on the last day," the trader said.
Friday is the last day of the weekly account on the Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE).
"Those that bought hoping that the market would shoot up further after the announcements were stunned and had to sell their positions," said a trader at another foreign brokerage.
He said foreign funds adopted a wait-and-see policy. Local funds sold in early trade and positions later in the session.
Prime Minister H.D. Deve Gowda on Monday reiterated his promise to unveil a market package before he departed for the World Economic Forum summit in Switzerland on Friday.
But traders' hopes were crushed late on Thursday after Finance Minister P. Chidambaram told newsmen the package was comprised of a series of measures announced earlier in January.
"Everyone was stunned," said the chief dealer of a foreign brokerage. "It was like a blow on the head."
"Even the measures announced by the market regulator were not really market-moving," he said.

The Securities and Exchange Board of India (SEBI) on Thursday said foreign investors would be allowed to invest in government debt. It cleared a proposal on securities lending and approved a new takeover code for companies.
-- Priya Ramani, Bombay equities desk, +91-22-265 9000
